> On 10/20/11, Sandy <magicquartz@...> wrote:
> > I hope you feel better=
 soon.  I just made a block buster chicken soup from
> > scratch to bring t=
o my friend's mom who was also  not feeling well.  And if
> > you have some=
one to make it for you, here's what you do.
> >
> > Ingredients:  One whole=
 chicken, three to four onions, a handful of parsley,
> > five of six carro=
ts, several stalks of celery, and a pinch of salt,
> > according to your ta=
ste.
> >
> > Put the whole chicken in a large soup pot, and pour just enoug=
h water over
> > the chicken to cover it.  Then add onions, carrots, celery=
 and then season
> > with salt according to your own taste.  Start the soup=
 on high until it
> > begins to boil, then lower to a slow to steady simmer=
 for two to three hours
> > or until the legs of the chicken are loose.  * =
Just lift the chicken out of
> > the pot with a pair of tongs and jiggle th=
e legs* .  Once the legs are
> > loose, you're ready to take the meat and v=
eggies out of the soup.  First
> > discard the parsley, which is only there=
 for flavor, then in a sparate
> > mixing bowl, you add the veggies and on =
a platter you put the chicken.
> > Allow meat and veggies to cool and then =
start by cutting the veggies into
> > bite sized pieces and put them back i=
nto the broth of the soup.  Then you
> > take the chicken off the bones, di=
scard skin, fat and bones, and shred the
> > meat into bite sized pieces an=
d put that back into the soup.  Once this is
> > done, turn off the heat an=
d allow the soup to cool. Once it cools down the
> > fat will rise to the t=
op and it will solidify.  When you're ready to eat it,
> > just skim the to=
p of the soup and remove the fat.  Heat to desired
> > temperature slowly a=
nd boil up your favorite pasta and most importantly,
> > ENJOY.
> >
> > Thi=
s is our family recipe that comes straight from Florence, Italy.  Trust
> >=
 me, you'll love it.
